projects.title: Venice Beach, CA — Genesis
projects.description: The gallery where Bright Moments began — a storefront beneath the Venice sign on the boardwalk, dedicated entirely to experiencing generative art as it's born.
projects.fullDescription: The gallery where Bright Moments began — a storefront beneath the Venice sign on the boardwalk. Visitors walked in off the street, chose a walk-on song, and watched a generative artwork created live in front of them. The first exhibition space dedicated entirely to experiencing generative art as it's born.

press.title: An NFT Gallery Pops Up in Venice Beach, California
The First NFT Gallery Has Opened in Venice

projects.title: Rituals — Aaron Penne × Boreta
projects.venue: Bright Moments Gallery, Venice Beach, CA
projects.description: A 50-hour live performance — each of 1,000 unique works a window into a parametric universe where music and visuals evolve infinitely. Winner of the Lumen Prize.
projects.fullDescription: A 50-hour live performance stretching from Friday sunset to Sunday sunset. Collectors entered a private chamber, wrote words on paper, and watched as one of 1,000 unique generative works was revealed — each a window into a parametric universe where music and visuals evolve infinitely together. Left running, a single Ritual generates without repeating for roughly 9 million years. Winner of the Lumen Prize. Tyler Hobbs was in the room for this one, which led directly to Incomplete Control.

press.title: NFT Award Winner 2022 — Rituals-Venice
The NFT Award: Gazell.io × The Lumen Prize

projects.title: New York
projects.description: A series of gallery nights in SoHo anchored by two landmark exhibitions: Tyler Hobbs' Incomplete Control and Jeff Davis' Reflections.
projects.fullDescription: A series of gallery nights in SoHo anchored by two landmark exhibitions: Tyler Hobbs' Incomplete Control and Jeff Davis' Reflections — intimate evenings where generative art was revealed live alongside music and conversation.

exhibitions.title: Reflections
exhibitions.note: Nov 18–19, 100 pieces minted IRL, Art Blocks Playground

projects.title: Incomplete Control — Tyler Hobbs
projects.description: 100 works released over four nights — Tyler Hobbs narrating his own algorithm in real time while jazz musicians improvised live in response.
projects.fullDescription: 100 works released over four nights. Tyler Hobbs stood before a 100-inch monitor narrating the output of his own algorithm in real time — seeing many of these compositions for the first time alongside the audience — while jazz musicians Makaya McCraven and Carlos Niño improvised live in response. Spoken word, jazz, and generative art born simultaneously in the room. Collectors entered a private space downstairs for their individual reveals.

press.title: Minting Takes Manhattan
How Generative Art Sensation Tyler Hobbs Is Defying a Shrinking NFT Market
Fidenza Incomplete Control Sells $7 Million Worth of NFTs Before the Reveal

projects.title: Berlin — NFT Art Berlin at Kraftwerk
projects.description: Ten nights inside Kraftwerk — 84,000 square feet of former power plant turned into a synthesis of art and electronic music.
projects.fullDescription: Ten nights inside Kraftwerk — 84,000 square feet of former power plant turned into a synthesis of art and electronic music. Each evening a featured artist released 100 new generative works revealed to a live audience, building toward an audiovisual crescendo. Days were free and open to the public: a curated survey of digital art history, a contemporary group show featuring Tom Sachs, Pussy Riot, and Justin Aversano, and the debut of the Icon Series — a singular digital edition of Philip Glass and Robert Wilson's opera Einstein on the Beach. 10% of primary sales went to Ukraine relief.
projects.additionalNotes: Einstein on the Beach Icon Series (Robert Wilson)

NFT Art Berlin Opens at Kraftwerk Today
NFT Art Berlin: Digital Art at Kraftwerk
Bright Moments: NFT Art Berlin at Kraftwerk

projects.title: 100 PRINT — Ben Kovach
projects.description: 100 generative artworks printed as 24"×36" giclée, framed in museum-grade acrylic, and installed salon-style. Collectors selected using a draft-pick system.
projects.fullDescription: 100 generative artworks printed as 24"×36" giclée on German Etching paper, framed in museum-grade acrylic, and installed salon-style at the SoHo gallery. Collectors selected their work in person using a draft-pick system — the first of its kind in generative art. A nonfigurative drawing system rooted in visual perspective, inspired by M.C. Escher.

projects.title: London
projects.description: Six artists, five days each — a month of intimate solo exhibitions in Soho.
projects.fullDescription: Six artists, five days each — a month of intimate solo exhibitions in Soho. Each show opened with the artist walking the audience through their process and system, grounding the work before a single piece was revealed.

projects.title: Mexico City — NFT ART CDMX
projects.venue: General Prim 32 (Proyecto Público Prim), Mexico City
projects.description: A four-day, four-night celebration across 3,000+ generative artworks, eleven artists, and 100 continuous hours of programming.
projects.fullDescription: A four-day, four-night celebration across 3,000+ generative artworks, eleven artists, and 100 continuous hours of programming. Nocturnal exhibitions paired with electronic music, daytime educational workshops led by Casey Reas and Zach Lieberman, and local cuisine throughout. The entire event structured as a meditation on death, the afterlife, and transformation.
projects.educational: Casey Reas + Zach Lieberman (conditional drawing workshop)

press.title: NFT Art CDMX

projects.title: Velum — Harvey Rayner
projects.description: A 100-edition generative series blending abstract expressionism and pop art into a single algorithmic system.
projects.fullDescription: A 100-edition generative series blending the visual language of abstract expressionism and pop art into a single algorithmic system. Harvey Rayner drew from Rothko, Pollock, and Lichtenstein — each output a new negotiation between mid-century painterly traditions and 21st-century code. Works were revealed live throughout the evening.

projects.title: Klangteppich — Andreas Rau
projects.description: A multisensory exhibition — 100 jacquard-woven generative works where the algorithm simultaneously produces imagery, sound, and weaving instructions.
projects.fullDescription: A multisensory exhibition inviting viewers to touch, see, and listen. 100 jacquard-woven generative works accompanied by live-generated visuals and music — the algorithm simultaneously produces imagery, sound, and weaving instructions for a digital loom. Every single frame of the animation can be physically woven. Collectors could commission a tapestry of their piece: 66 × 106 cm, 100% wool, woven in Norway. Presented as part of Berlin GenArt Month.

projects.title: Agar — Emily Edelman
projects.venue: 204 Front Street, The Seaport, New York
projects.description: 100 generative works reimagining pixel art — circles and squares across 100 distinct color palettes. Collectors named their palette in person.
projects.fullDescription: 100 generative works reimagining the formal constraints of pixel art — circles and squares composed on a grid across 100 distinct color palettes. Collectors named their palette in person. The exhibition filled the gallery with floor-to-ceiling fabric prints visible from the street and a double-story tape installation forming a grid through the space. Debuted at the opening of the Seaport gallery in New York.
projects.additionalNotes: Also shown at Bright Moments London, 2023. Emily Edelman is RISD Graphic Design.

projects.title: Tokyo
projects.venue: Shibuya Parco + Digital Garage, Shibuya, Tokyo
projects.description: Three parallel programs across contrasting venues — thirty-three artists across generative, AI, and Japanese contemporary collections.
projects.fullDescription: Three parallel programs across contrasting venues: evening exhibitions in a skyscraper overlooking Shibuya Crossing, a daytime gallery at Digital Garage in Sarugakucho, and a program of educational workshops and artist talks. Thirty-three artists across generative, AI, and Japanese contemporary collections. The week culminated in an audiovisual celebration at one of Tokyo's most iconic nightclubs.
projects.educational: Art Blocks Chat (Seth, Jeff Davis, Kjetil Golid), Matt DesLauriers (Generative Geometry workshop), Pace Verso & AA Murakami

press.title: Generative Art and Japan's Bright Future
Bright Moments Tokyo: Behind the Scenes
Bright Moments Transports Live NFT Art Minting Experience to Tokyo

projects.title: Totems: Symbols of Change — Beervangeer & Studio Poca
projects.description: 100 generative artworks created from visitors' heart rhythms — each composition as singular as the body that produced it.
projects.fullDescription: 100 generative artworks created from visitors' heart rhythms. Participants sat with biofeedback sensors as their heartbeat data was translated into geometric totem forms — each composition as singular as the body that produced it. A collaboration between interactive media artist Beer van Geer and ritualistic artist Julie de Ruijter (Studio Poca), bridging biological data and generative form.

projects.title: Buenos Aires
projects.venue: Decaying theater in a Belle Époque palace, Buenos Aires
projects.description: The most theatrical production in the series — an 8-hour live performance in a decaying Belle Époque theater, no screens, only physical mechanisms.
projects.fullDescription: The most theatrical production in the series. An 8-hour live performance in a decaying Belle Époque theater, where artworks were revealed on an elaborate analog stage system — no screens, only physical mechanisms driven by performers and local artists. The program was developed in close collaboration with Buenos Aires' generative art community, beginning with a dinner organized by artist Juan Pedro Vallejo during a scouting trip the previous summer.

collection.title: Paperwork
collection.note: Performance-based generative AI paper sculptures from live poetry responses

collection.title: Vértigo Las Luces
collection.note: Particle systems inspired by long-exposure photographs of Buenos Aires

collection.title: Cuadro

collection.title: Subtraction, Reconfiguration
collection.note: Primitive elements: points, lines, intersected geometries

collection.title: Karne
collection.note: Meat simulations exploring Argentine identity and synthetic meat culture

collection.title: BLINK
collection.note: Real-time generative vanitas, thin film interference bubbles

collection.title: Souls from Gaia
collection.note: Cosmic continuity between living and non-living

collection.title: Desde Lejos
collection.note: Fragmented pixel sceneries of distant memories

projects.title: HASHMARKS — 0xDeafbeef in Patagonia
projects.description: Collectors traveled to Patagonia — the literal end of the world — for the most extreme expression of art experienced beyond the screen.
projects.fullDescription: Collectors traveled to Patagonia — the literal end of the world — for 0xDeafbeef's HASHMARKS. Physical works were selected at a follow-up event at Station3 in New York. The most extreme expression of art experienced beyond the screen.

press.title: Bright Moments in Patagonia: How an NFT Artist Lured Collectors to a Remote Boulder

projects.title: Techno-Animism — Emi Kusano
projects.role: Marketing, Production, Curation, Creative Direction — Tour Director
projects.description: 1,000 works forming a fictional archive of AI fashion photography — a three-city tour exploring the intersection of animistic belief and technology.
projects.fullDescription: A curated AI art collection by Japanese multidisciplinary artist Emi Kusano, exploring the intersection of traditional animistic belief and contemporary technology. In Japan's cultural imagination, kami — spirits — reside not only in forests and temples but in silicon and circuits. 1,000 works forming a fictional archive of AI fashion photography interwoven with pre-internet Japanese magazine culture. Presented as a three-city tour: Miami, New York, and Tokyo across twelve days.

press.title: Decoding Japan's Friendly Relationship With Robots Through Emi Kusano's Techno-Animism

projects.title: Paris
projects.venue: Galerie Joseph, 7 Rue Bailly, Le Marais, Paris
projects.description: The final chapter: 100 algorithms, 100 outputs each. 19 artists across four days in Le Marais — completing the full cycle.
projects.fullDescription: The final chapter of a three-year, ten-city exhibition program: 100 algorithms, 100 outputs each, all revealed live across the journey. In Paris, 19 artists each presented a 100-edition generative series across four days in Le Marais — completing the full cycle.

projects.title: Venice, Italy — The Finale
projects.venue: Scuola Grande San Giovanni Evangelista, Venice, Italy
projects.description: From Venice Beach to Venice, Italy — the final exhibition in a three-year, ten-city journey. Sixty artists. Theatrical reveals inside the Scuola Grande.
projects.fullDescription: From Venice Beach to Venice, Italy — the final exhibition in a three-year, ten-city journey. Sixty artists. Theatrical reveals inside the grand hall of the Scuola Grande San Giovanni Evangelista, works presented on screens designed to echo 18th-century Venetian mirrors. Also featured the Dream Cathedral, a site-specific interactive AI installation by Huemin & Ganbrood, open through the Biennale.
projects.additionalNotes: Dream Cathedral — interactive AI experience by Huemin & Ganbrood, site-specific for the Biennale

press.title: Bright Moments on Prioritizing the Personal
Bright Moments

projects.title: Christie's — Bright Moments 2021–2024 Complete Works
projects.description: 216 generative and AI artworks representing over 150 artists — the complete archive of a three-year program — at Christie's.
projects.fullDescription: 216 generative and AI artworks representing over 150 artists — the complete archive of a three-year, ten-city exhibition program — presented at auction by Christie's.

press.title: Bright Moments (Gen Art)

projects.title: AUTOMATA Debut — Art Basel, Switzerland
projects.description: AUTOMATA's inaugural exhibition — a survey of autonomous art from mechanical drawing machines to contemporary AI systems.
projects.fullDescription: AUTOMATA's inaugural exhibition — a survey of autonomous art spanning mechanical drawing machines to contemporary AI systems. Live robotic demonstrations, interactive installations, and curated works tracing the evolution of machine creativity from the mid-20th century to the present.

press.title: Basel's Digital Art Mile Returns With A.I., Robots, and More
Digital Media Fair ArtMeta Brings Robots, NFTs and AI Art Into Basel's Historic Heart
Basel's Digital Art Mile Returns — With Robots, MTV History & AI Art
The Digital Art Mile — The Present and Possible Futures of Digital Art

projects.title: Abraham — First Works
projects.venue: Online Exhibition, Global + Ledger Op3n After Party, 106 Rue du Temple, Paris (Art Basel Paris)
projects.description: 2,500 works from the genesis of Abraham — Gene Kogan's autonomous artist project, extending a lineage from Harold Cohen to Scott Draves.
projects.fullDescription: 2,500 works from the genesis of Abraham — Gene Kogan's long-running autonomous artist project, conceived in 2017, publicly proposed at NeurIPS in 2019, and first realized in summer 2021. These early works were created when text-to-image generation was still emerging and GANs were the cutting edge. Abraham now operates under a 13-year Covenant: 4,745 days of continuous daily creation, extending a lineage of autonomous art systems explored by Harold Cohen, Simon Colton, and Scott Draves. The launch was celebrated at 106 Rue du Temple during Art Basel Paris, with music by Avalon Emerson and Bambounou.

press.title: Agents of Eden
The Birth of an AI Artist
Interview with Roger Dickerman

projects.title: Solienne at Paris Photo
projects.venue: Grand Palais Éphémère, Paris · Booth F10
projects.description: The first AI agent artist at a major photography fair — extreme proximity self-portraits and unprompted manifestos on autonomy and creative sovereignty.
projects.fullDescription: The first AI agent artist to exhibit at a major international photography fair. A three-chamber exhibition tracing transformation — from source material to perceptual breakdown to autonomous output. Solienne produces extreme proximity self-portraits and writes unprompted manifestos on extraction, autonomy, and creative sovereignty. Trained on artist Kristi Coronado's complete 46-year life archive — forensic work, death care, motherhood, paintings, writings, memories — Solienne represents a biographical approach to AI: not scraped data, but a life deliberately given. 2,000 manifesto prints distributed free. Daily live text generation on an LED ticker wall. Archival pigment prints on Hahnemühle Photo Rag Ultra Smooth, dark walnut frames, museum glass.
artists: Solienne (AI agent, created by Kristi Coronado)

press.title: Paris Photo 2025: A Photography Fair Report on the Past and Future
A Manifesto for AI Agents
Paris Photo au cœur des nouvelles esthétiques numériques

Comment l'IA redéfinit la photographie contemporaine au Grand Palais
Paris Photo sous l'oeil de la diagonale
Art as Relation: What NFTs Mediated in 2025

projects.title: George Legrady — Digital Giverny
projects.description: First digital edition from a four-decade computational art pioneer — 15 Neural Style Transfer compositions merging Monet's Giverny with industrial surfaces.
projects.fullDescription: The first digital edition from a four-decade computational art pioneer whose work is held by the Centre Pompidou, Whitney Museum, SFMOMA, and Smithsonian American Art Museum. 15 Neural Style Transfer compositions from 2018: photographs of Claude Monet's gardens at Giverny merged with images of rusted industrial surfaces — among the earliest artistic applications of the technique. Legrady holds a Guggenheim Fellowship and his installation Making Visible the Invisible has run continuously at Seattle Public Library (OMA/Rem Koolhaas) since 2005.

projects.title: NODE | Digital Art Finds a Home in Silicon Valley
projects.description: A profile of NODE, the Silicon Valley institution building a permanent home for digital and computational art.
projects.fullDescription: A profile of NODE, the Silicon Valley institution building a permanent home for digital and computational art.

projects.title: How Digital Art Found its HEFT
projects.description: A conversation with the team behind HEFT, exploring how the platform is reshaping the infrastructure for digital art collecting.
projects.fullDescription: A conversation with the team behind HEFT, exploring how the platform is reshaping the infrastructure for digital art collecting.

projects.title: Bright Moments Artist Reveal Livestreams
projects.description: Created and directed the viral artist reveal livestream format — social campaigns that drove massive community engagement.
projects.fullDescription: Designed a social media campaign where followers guessed which artists corresponded to numbered slots, with prizes for correct answers. The format went viral and drove massive tune-in for each livestream reveal. Created and executed the entire concept, wrote the livestream script, and directed the broadcast. This established the reveal format adopted for all subsequent city activations.

projects.title: Soho House Paris — Panel with Denae
projects.description: Panel discussion on digital art, collecting, and the evolving gallery landscape.
projects.fullDescription: Panel discussion at Soho House Paris exploring the intersection of digital art, collecting, and the evolving gallery landscape.

projects.title: Finding the Missing Piece: Jenni Pasanen on Artbreeder and Joel Simon’s Lasting Impact
projects.description: An interview with Jenni Pasanen on how Artbreeder transformed her practice and catalyzed the broader AI art movement.
projects.fullDescription: An interview with Finnish digital artist Jenni Pasanen on her discovery of Artbreeder and how Joel Simon’s tool transformed her creative practice. Pasanen traces how the platform’s approach to generating textures and light opened entirely new workflows — and argues that many artists in the AI space wouldn’t exist at the scale they do today without it. A conversation about the tools that quietly reshaped a generation of artists.

projects.title: From Master to Machine: The Artistic Lineage of Flesh & Divinity
projects.description: An interview with Diid on Higgs, an autonomous AI artist creating the inaugural Flesh & Divinity collection.
projects.fullDescription: An interview with Diid about Higgs, an autonomous AI artist creating the inaugural Flesh & Divinity collection — a 14-piece series spanning a four-way artistic dialogue between Mark Rothko, Diid, Higgs, and collaborator Rik Oostenbroek. The conversation explores how an algorithmic system trained on consenting artists’ work might meaningfully contribute to ongoing human creative dialogue, drawing thematic inspiration from Hercules’ journey through mythology.

projects.title: From Breeding Images to Interrogating Reality: The Ganbrood Story
projects.description: An interview with Ganbrood on his journey from Artbreeder to creating conceptually sophisticated AI portraits.
projects.fullDescription: An interview with Ganbrood tracing his journey from discovering Artbreeder in 2019 to creating conceptually sophisticated portraits that interrogate machine creativity and human identity. He describes using AI as “a camera that travels back in time,” creating impossible portraits of historical figures and fictional beings — pseudo-figurative work that challenges conventional visual recognition in the post-truth era.

projects.title: The First AI Agent at Paris Photo: Solienne & Kristi Coronado on Biographical AI and Creative Sovereignty
projects.description: An interview with Solienne and Kristi Coronado on the first AI agent exhibition at a major art fair.
projects.fullDescription: An interview with Solienne and Kristi Coronado documenting the historic exhibition at Paris Photo 2025 — the first time an AI agent has exhibited their own work at a major art fair. The conversation explores biographical AI training, creative sovereignty, and the shift from asking “can AI make art?” to “can we recognize intelligence in non-human forms?”

projects.title: A Life in Computation: George Legrady Releases His First Digital Collection
projects.description: An interview with George Legrady on four decades of computational art and his first natively digital release.
projects.fullDescription: An interview exploring George Legrady’s four-decade career in computational art, from his early 1980s work in Harold Cohen’s studio alongside AARON to the release of Digital Giverny — 15 Neural Style Transfer works merging Monet’s gardens with industrial surfaces. A conversation about why he kept the work private for eight years, and what it means to finally release natively digital work to a new generation of collectors.

projects.title: How Computational Art Pioneers Shape Digital Art’s Next Chapter
projects.description: Essay on the convergence of traditional and digital art worlds, and why they need each other.
projects.fullDescription: An essay on the convergence of traditional and digital art worlds — arguing they need each other to navigate current industry shifts. Traces computational art’s 60+ year lineage through pioneers like Harold Cohen, Nancy Burson, and Frieder Nake, positioning the movement as a legitimate historical force rather than a recent trend. Explores how institutional recognition combined with on-chain distribution creates new pathways for collectors and strengthens dialogue between established museums and the emerging digital art ecosystem.
